Dear Melynda Elizabeth Williams:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Program Statement
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4109
Section (1) An institution shall have and follow a current written program
Description statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission, care, safety,
and supervision, methods for addressing residents’ needs,
implementation of treatment plans, and discharge of residents
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth were in a car accident. A parent of one of the children
reported staff was doing donuts in the agency van and flipped the
van causing the children needing to go to the emergency room.
Investigation Foster Care Worker 1 was interviewed via phone on
4/19/2024. She reported finding out about the allegations
yesterday during a visit Youth A had with Youth A’s mother. Youth
A informed Foster Care Worker 1 Youth A was informed by staff
that “staff don’t lie for staff”. Youth A didn’t disclose the full story of
the accident but indicated it occurred after Youth A’s visit to Youth
A’s grandmother’s home. Foster Care Worker 1 also received an
2

email (reviewed below) from the facility about the accident on
4/7/2024.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
4/24/2024. She reported knowing of the incident involving the
accident but was not present the day it occurred.
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on
4/24/2024 and interviewed face to face at school on 4/26/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth A reported being in
the van on 4/7/24 when Staff 4 flipped the van in a parking lot. He
reported Staff 4 was doing “donuts” and when the back wheel,
tires locked, and the van flipped landing on the passenger side.
Youth A reported asking Staff 4 to do donuts and Youth B, Youth
C, Youth D, and Youth E agreed with Staff 4 doing donuts. Staff 5
and Staff 6 said nothing when Youth A asked Staff 4 to do donuts
and began to drive in this manner. Youth A reported Staff 4 was
“drifting” the van just before hitting the turn and flipping the van.
Youth A reported Staff 4 told Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D,
and Youth E to tell the police and others that Staff 4 was just
trying to turn, and the van flipped. Staff 4 said this prior to the
police showing up. Youth A reported no one was hurt in the
accident and all of the youth involved were examined after being
taken to the hospital in an ambulance. Youth A reported feeling
safe at the facility.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at school on 4/26/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth B reported being in
the van driven by Staff 4 when the van flipped onto its passenger
side. Youth B reported the accident took place in the parking lot of
a local park. Youth B believed because of the number of
individuals (Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, Staff 4,
Staff 5, and Staff 6) in the van and when Staff 4 turned into the
parking lot, the shift in weight caused the van to flip. The flip
occurred because of the weight causing the van to “pop-up” and
locked the wheels. Youth B reported the tipping over was slow.
Youth B reported a belief that the van had mechanical issues and
needed maintenance as reasons that contributed to the flipping.
Youth B reported never observing Staff 4 drive reckless when
Youth B has been a passenger with Staff 4 driving. Staff 4 nor
anyone else told Youth B what to say or not say about the
accident. Youth B reported Staff 4 is his “primary” staff and they
have a good relationship with Youth B liking Staff 4 a great deal.
Youth B feels safe at the facility.
3

Youth D was interviewed face to face at school on 4/26/2024
in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth D reported being in
the van driven by Staff 4 on 4/7/24 when the van flipped on the
passenger side. Youth D reported Staff 4 was “doing donuts and
drifting” with the van prior to the van flipping. This occurred in a
local park and Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, Youth E, Staff
5, and Staff 6 were also in the van at the time. Youth D
remembered Staff 4 said he was going to do donuts and drift but
could not remember Staff 5 and Staff 6’s response to Staff 4 but is
sure they did say something. Youth D reported Staff 4 had done
“drifting” in the past (unable to recall specifics) but didn’t flip the
van when doing so. Youth D reported Staff 5 and Staff 6 told
Youth D to tell the truth about the accident and no one told Youth
D not to tell the truth. Youth D reported feeling safe at the facility.
Staff 6 was interviewed face to face at the main campus on
5/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
understanding the reason for this interview and was present in the
van during the incident. He reported the trip in the van began at
main campus and the group (Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D,
Youth E, Staff 4, Staff 6, and Staff 5) were headed back to the
facility. Staff 4 was driving and as he drew close to the facility,
Staff 4 turned into a small park at a high rate of speed, and
someone (unidentified) said “buckle up because here we go”. Staff
6 reported being hired at the facility approximately a month and a
half ago and that this was the first-time riding in the van with Staff
4 driving. Staff 6 had the impression that this has occurred before
because of the reaction of Staff 4 and Youth A, Youth B, Youth C,
Youth D, and Youth E in the van. Staff 4 drove onto the grass and
did a couple of donuts before driving to the pavement and doing
three donuts. Staff 6 described the situation as like a “monster
truck on the grass and a Dodge Charger on the pavement”. Staff 6
reported sitting in the last seat against the window and when Staff
4 turned the van in the opposite direction to begin another donut,
the van flipped onto its passenger side. Staff 6 reported yelling at
Staff 4 to stop throughout the incident but believed the youth
“yelling to go” kept Staff 4 engaged in the reckless driving. Staff 6
believed they were going approximately 65 to 70 miles per hour at
times. Staff 6 reported not knowing if the youth were buckled in
with seat belts and believds only Youth B may have been using a
seat belt. Since Staff 6 just began his employment, he reported
being unsure of the seat belt rules. Staff 6 reported Staff 5 didn’t
say anything to Staff 4 during the reckless driving and appeared to
be “holding on for dear life”. Staff 6 reported Staff 4 had asked the
youth in the van (Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth
E) if they saw Staff 4’s moves while driving. Staff 6 reported
4

hurting his shoulder in the accident and when at the hospital, Staff
4 confronted Staff 6 and was mad that Staff 6 would tell the truth
about the cause of the accident. Staff 6 reported Staff 4 called
Staff 6 a “snitch and to get the fuck out of his face”. Staff 4
informed Staff 6 that Staff 6 will see what can happen to Staff 6
after work because Staff 6 will never see it coming. Staff 6 was
unable to identify which youth were hurt. Staff 6 reported avoiding
contact with Staff 4 once back at the facility but did report some of
the youth (unable to identify) told him Staff 4 had asked them to lie
about the cause of the accident.
Staff 5 was interviewed face to face at the main campus on
5/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported
being in the van during the incident and reported they were
heading to the facility from the main campus. Youth A had asked
Staff 4 to “spin the van” on the way so Staff 4 pulled into the
“Broom Park”. Staff 5 reported Staff 4 was driving approximately
50 to 60 miles per hour when pulling into the park and started
doing donuts on the pavement. Staff 4 then did donuts in the
grass before driving back on the pavement and doing more
donuts. Staff 5 believed Staff 4 did 4 or 5 more donuts on the
pavement before the van flipped on the passenger side. Staff 5
reported sitting on the passenger side just behind the passenger
seat at the time. Staff 5 reported being upset over Staff 4’s driving
but not saying anything to Staff 4 about the reckless driving. Staff
5 reported having regrets over not speaking up. Staff 5 reported
never observing Staff 4 drive reckless before but believed it has
occurred before because Youth A told Staff 4 to spin the van and
Staff 4 appeared to understand what Youth A was saying. Staff 5
was unsure if all of the youth (Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth
D, and Youth E) were wearing seatbelts but was sure Youth A
was because Youth A was sitting next to Staff 5. Staff 5 reported
Staff 4 didn’t ask Staff 5 to lie about the accident and Staff 5 never
spoke to Staff 4 following the accident. Staff 5 was unaware of
what Staff 4 told Law Enforcement after the accident or what Staff
4 said to the youth (Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and
Youth E) following the accident. Staff 5 reported Staff 4 did take
responsibility for the accident and called management and told
management there was an accident.
Youth C was interviewed face-to-face at the school on
5/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth C
reported blacking out during the accident with the van flipping. He
reported sitting in the third row behind the driver’s seat. Youth C
reported Youth A, Youth B, and Youth E all asked Staff 4 to do
donuts after they entered the park near the facility. Staff 5 and
5

Staff 6 didn’t say anything to Staff 4 about stopping the van and
donuts. Youth C was unable to identify if Staff 4 said anything
because Staff 4 was playing the music loud at the time. Youth C
reported believing Staff 4 did approximately 5 donuts in the
parking lot with some of the donuts on the grass and others on the
pavement. Youth C reported the van flipped on its passenger side
and he was unsure who was cut by glass but believes someone
was. Youth C reported Staff 4 has done donuts when Youth C
was in the van in the past. He reported Staff 4 would cut corners
fast and drifting at times when driving. Youth C was unable to
recall who the other youth in the van was at the time this occurred.
A second time Staff 4 was driving like this occurred in the same
park when Staff 4 did 6 donuts after picking up Youth C from
school. Youth C reported Youth A, Youth B, Youth E, and Staff 9
along with a youth, Youth C could not name. Youth C reported
having his seatbelt on, but the other youth (Youth A, Youth B, and
Youth E) did not have their seatbelts on. Youth C denied Staff 4
threaten youth to tell a false story. Youth C reported feeling safe at
the facility.
Staff 4 was interviewed face-to-face in the parking lot of a
grocery story on 5/8/2024 in collaboration with MDHHS
worker. Staff 4 denied the allegations of doing donuts, and drifting
the van with youth (Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and
Youth E) and staff (Staff 5 and Staff 6) in the van. He reported
driving a “little fast” but not “speeding much”. He denied driving on
the grass and when trying to make a left turn in a narrow part of
the pavement, the back wheel “locked” and the van tilted causing
the accident. He denied making the skid marks in the parking lot
because they were too small to have been made by the van. Staff
4 admitted to doing “circles” in the parking lot but not “donuts”.
Staff 4 reported only going about 15-miles per hour when doing
“circles” and engaged in this activity to “waste” time before
returning to the facility. Staff 4 reported a belief that because of
the number of passengers in the van this contributed to the van
tipping over. Staff 4 reported all of the passengers in the van had
their seatbelts on as required. He reported not threatening or
telling the youth what to say when asked by Law Enforcement and
suggested he was threatened by Staff 6.
Youth E was interviewed via phone on 5/10/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. Youth E reported moving
from the facility approximately a month ago and is now living in
independent living setting. He reported being in the facility for
approximately a year and left a day after the accident. He gave
the same information of who was in the van and seating location
6

as others interviewed. He reported wearing a seatbelt during the
ride but was unsure if other youth (Youth A, Youth B, Youth C,
and Youth D) were wearing their seatbelts. Youth E reported Staff
4 turned real fast and this caused the back wheel to lock and
when Staff 4 tried to make the wheel unlock it caused the van to
tip over. Youth E denied Staff 4 was doing any donuts nor driving
fast in the park. Youth E reported not paying attention to what was
going on, so he didn’t hear any other youth (Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, and Youth D) ask Staff 4 to do donuts. Youth E recalled
Staff 4 said something after the accident but was unable to recall
what was said. Youth E ended by saying he was not paying
attention to what anyone else was doing so he didn’t know if Staff
4 was doing donuts or not.
Staff 9 was interviewed via phone on 5/16/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported not being
present at the time of the accident. He reported never witnessing
Staff 4 doing donuts when they both worked at the facility. Staff 4
worked a different shift and Staff 9 was unable to recall knowing of
any incident when Staff 4 was driving reckless. Staff 9 had no
concerns with Staff 4 even though Staff 9 had not worked the
same location as Staff 4 for the past 4 months.
Staff 7 was interviewed via phone on 5/16/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. She reported being the first
staff responding to the accident and on the scene. She reported
her primary focus was making sure the youth (Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, and Youth D) were ok and calm. She reported observing
all staff (Staff 4, Staff 5, and Staff 6) and youth (Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, and Youth D) standing outside of the van when arriving.
Law Enforcement was also present. She reported no one said
anything specific about the accident but someone (unidentified
staff or youth) told Staff 7, the van was pulling into the parking lot,
and it flipped. She reported “hearing something about donuts” but
could not remember who provided this information. She described
Staff 4 as a “good staff” who cared for the youth.
Staff 8 was interviewed via phone on 5/16/2024 in
collaboration with MDHHS worker. He reported responding to a
call from Staff 7 about the accident. When Staff 8 arrived on scene
he observed Staff 5, and Staff 6 and youth(Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, and Youth D standing outside of the van and Law
Enforcement present. Staff 4 was being treated by medical
personal. After checking with the youth and having them tell Staff
8 that when turning, the wheel locked up, he spoke with Staff 4
who provided the same information. Staff 5 provided the same
7

information, but Staff 6 took Staff 8 to the side away from others
and reported the youth (Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, and Youth D)
and staff (Staff 4 and Staff 5) had lied about the cause of the
accident. Staff 6 informed Staff 8 that Staff 4 was doing donuts
which caused the accident. Staff 8 reported having no prior
concerns with Staff 4’s driving and that Staff 4 “seems alright with
his interactions with the youth”.
Documents Reviewed:
Email from the facility (Administrator 1) to DCWL consultant
on 2/24/2024. This email indicates Youth A, Youth B, and Youth F
were involved in an automobile accident when the vehicle they
were riding in was hit on the driver’s side as they were going
through an intersection on the way back to the campus. Youth A,
Youth B, and Youth F were transported to the hospital by
ambulance and later released. There were no serious injuries and
Youth B was given a script for pain. The driver of the van was
Staff 4.
Email from the facility (Staff 2) to Foster Care Worker 1 on
4/7/2024. This email outlines Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D,
Youth E were in a vehicle accident on the way back to the campus
on 4/7/2024. It also indicates the youth were observed at the
hospital and released with no serious injuries.
Email from the facility (Staff 3) to MDHHS Worker on
4/22/2024. Staff 3 reported the incident in the allegations occurred
on 4/7/24 and involved Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and
Youth E along with Staff 4 (driver), Staff 5, and Staff 6 (driver).
She reported there were no injuries and Staff 4 was ticketed for
Reckless Driving and the facility terminated his employment.
Email from the facility (Staff 3) to MDHHS Worker on
4/24/2024. She advises MDHHS worker that it would be unwise to
interview Staff 4 on campus since it has been reported that he
made threats to Staff 5 and Staff 6 for those who snitch on him.
Email from Foster Care Worker 5 on 4/25/2024. She reported
Youth E was a witness to the accident since Youth E was a
passenger in the van at the time of the accident. Youth E informed
Foster Care Worker 5 that Staff 4 was taking a curve to fast and
lost control. Youth E also denied Staff 4 was doing donuts with the
van.
Whaley Children’s Center Incident Report dated 4/7/24 (or
4/9/24) authored by Staff 4. This document outlines Staff 4’s
8

recall of the accident on 4/7/24 with the van. It is documented “we”
were driving around the park and when turning around a corner
the wheel locked up and the van titled. It is also documented “a
staff (unidentified) repeatedly pointed at me telling me I’m fired
and done for”. This document is signed by Staff 4.
Whaley Children’s Center Incident Report dated 4/7/24 and
authored by Staff 5. This document outlines the incident in the
allegations and does not identify the driver of the van by name but
rather states “staff who was operating the vehicle”. It is noted the
driver went to the park at the request of the youth (unidentified)
and began to pick up speed (“speed that is higher than normal”)
and started “making sharp turns”. After doing this a few times, the
driver lost control during a turn and the van fell on its side.
Whaley Children’s Center Incident Report dated 4/7/24 and
authored by Staff 5. This is the second incident report for the
incident on 4/7/24 authored by Staff 5. This document outlines,
they were driving down the street on the way to the park when
staff tried to turn and the “wheel locked which caused the van to
tip over”.
Whaley Children’s Center Incident Report dated 4/7/24 and
authored by Staff 6. This incident report of the incident on 4/7/24
indicates that rather than returning to the facility, staff (unidentified
in report) chose to go to a park and “do donuts all over the place”.
While doing donuts on the grass at the park, causing the car to
“flip over”. It is documented that “no wheel lock up took place”.
Whaley Children’s Center Incident Report dated 4/7/24 and
authored by Staff 7. This document outlines, Staff 7 being
notified of the accident and going to the scene of the accident. It is
documented that once at the scene, Staff 7 observed Youth A,
Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Youth E out of the van. Staff 4,
Staff 5, and Staff 6 were also out of the van at this time. The driver
(unidentified) informed Staff 7 that the “wheels locked up causing
the van to tip”. Staff 7 contacted management and followed the
ambulance to the hospital.
Whaley Children’s Center Incident Report dated 4/7/24 and
authored by Staff 8. This document outlines Staff 8’s actions
after receiving information about the accident. Staff 8 went to the
scene and also went to the hospital. At the hospital, a staff
(unidentified) informed Staff 8 that another staff (unidentified)
pointing at him. Staff 8 spoke with both staff (unidentified) and
resolved the issue.
9

Whaley Children’s Center Incident Reports dated 4/8/24,
authored by Staff 7 for Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D
and Youth E. It is documented Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth
D and Youth E was in the accident and taken to the hospital.
Youth A, Youth B, Youth C, Youth D and Youth E is reported to
have had no injuries from the accident.
Whaley Children’s Center Incident Report dated 4/8/24,
authored by Staff 1 for Youth A. It is documented Youth A
shared being upset that a staff (unidentified) was lying on Youth
A’s favorite staff which would cause Youth A to act out. Youth A
refused to identify the two staff and then refused to speak about
the incident anymore.
Whaley Children’s Center Incident Report dated 4/8/24,
authored by Staff 1 for Youth B. It is documented Youth B
asked Staff 1 who was working later in the day and when told a
specific staff (unidentified), Youth B became upset reporting that
the specific staff (unidentified) is a “snitch”. Youth B reported he
will “begin telling on this specific staff (unidentified) for no reason”.
Hurley Medical Center after visit summary Youth A dated
4/7/24. This document outlines Youth A suffered an “abrasion of
right lower extremity” and it is recommended Youth A take Tylenol
and/or Motrin for pain. Ice is also recommended to help with pain
and swelling.
Hurley Medical Center after visit summary Youth D dated
4/7/24. Youth D presented with no acute symptoms and denied
any head or neck pain.
Hurley Medical Center after visit summary Youth E dated
4/7/24. Youth E presented with no acute symptoms and denied
any head or neck pain.
Hurley Medical Center after visit summary Youth C dated
4/7/24. Youth C presented with lost of consciousness right after
the accident, right shoulder pain, right thigh pain and mild frontal
headache where he hit his head. The pain in his right shoulder
and right thigh have been resolved. At discharge, Youth C was
given pain control and should have a pediatrician re-evaluation.
Hurley Medical Center after visit summary Youth B dated
4/7/24. Youth B injured his right ankle and received x-rays at the
hospital. There appeared to be soft tissue swelling and a follow up
appointment was to occur with specialty pediatrics.
10

Whaley Children’s Center Driver’s License and Driving record
Policy dated 10/27/23. This document outlines the requirements
of staff in regard to their driver’s license. Staff are required to have
a valid and unrestricted driver’s license. If staff receive a moving
vehicle ticket or license is suspended, they are to notify
administration immediately. If staff do not have insurance or are
unable to drive will be placed on a 10-day suspension period or
until the issue is resolved.
Whaley Children’s Center Whaley Vehicles WCC Residential
Policies & Procedures Section 1, Part D Policy dated 1/2024.
This document outlines staff’s responsibilities when transporting
youth. The primary issue of consideration is identified as safety.
This includes all occupants must be in a seat belt.
Whaley Children’s Center Professional Boundaries and
Personal Involvement with Children (WCC Residential
Policies & Procedures Section II, Part A) dated 12/2020. This
document outlines the expectations of staff and their interactions
with the youth in the program. It states, “requires every staff
member to be a positive leader and role model”. Staff are also
expected to teach the youth appropriate behaviors. Interactions
with the youth are intended to create a sense of protection and
support and at all times staff are considered role models,
presenting expected behaviors. It is also documented that at no
time are staff to exhibit inappropriate behaviors.
Flint Police Department Field Case Report 2024-00110023
dated 4/7/24 @ 7:34 PM. This document outlines the findings of
Law Enforcement when investigating the accident in this
complaint. Staff 4 is identified as a “adult Suspect”. Law
Enforcement responded to an “unknown accident involving a red
van” at Broome Park. Law enforcement observed the van laying
on it’s passenger side on the pavement with “several black tire
skid marks in a circular pattern” on the pavement. Law
Enforcement also noted there were tire marks in the grass that
lined up to the circular marks on the pavement. Mud on the back
of the van was consistent with the marks in the grass and mud. It
is documented, the Law Enforcement investigation revealed that
Staff 4 had been driving recklessly in the parking lot and when the
wheel caught on the pavement, it caused the van to roll over. It is
documented that Staff 4 informed Law Enforcement that he was
driving speeds approximately at 15-miles per hour and when the
front wheels got stuck in the right turn position the vehicle started
11

rolling over. It is documented that Staff 4 was issued a citation for
reckless driving.
Whaley Children’s Center Progressive Discipline Notification
Form dated 4/8/2024 for Staff 4. This document outlines Staff 4’s
termination from employment on 4/9/2024. It is documented that
Staff 4 began his employment on 8/14/23 and was within the
probationary period. This probationary period was for 9 calendar
months from date of hire, and it is documented that there were
concerns about Staff 4’s ability to grow into an effective employee.
It is documented that Staff 4 received “many coaching
opportunities from management” and is being terminated at this
time because of the accident and failure to grow into an effective
employee.
Staff 4’s personnel file: Documentation indicates Staff 4
completed orientation training (documented as 73 hours) on
8/25/2023. He also completed Professional Boundaries training on
8/24/23 and Defensive Driving on 8/20/23. At the time of the
incident, documentation shows Staff 4 was up to date on training
requirements. A progressive Discipline Notification Form dated
3/27/24 for Staff 4 was documented in the HR file. This form is
documented as a “written warning” for failure to sign the
“population book” for the week of 3/12/24 – 3/19/24. Staff 4 signed
this document on 3/28/24.
Analysis The facility is found in non-compliance as per interviews and
written documentation, Staff 4 did not follow agency policies when
Staff 4 drove recklessly with youth in the vehicle causing an
accident.
Technical assistance:
Technical assistance was offered that the agency retrain staff on
following driving laws, as well as licensing rules when transporting
youth. There were mixed reports of youth wearing their seatbelts
during this transport and it was recommended that some type of
documentation be developed to ensure youth are wearing
seatbelts. Technical assistance was offered that staff need to hold
other staff accountable to provide best practice care for the youth
in the program and report concerns immediately to supervisor.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
12

Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the current license status be continued.
